item.title: 10 Best Zombie Games No One Remembers
item.description:
When it comes to zombie games, most fans of this specific horror genre are probably going to think about Resident Evil and Dead Rising . They both belong to Capcom, which is a company that has carved out a nice little niche within the horror genre as a whole, and it’s a big reason why they have thrived for so long.

While there are many great entries in the Resident Evil and Dead Rising franchises, there are also some games that deserve more attention. Most of these examples only got one game before they were forgotten without much of a fan base. Some may be hard to track down and play nowadays, but they will still provide some unique zombie experiences that are worth a laugh or two.

Dead Head Fred

Brain Dead

Dead Head Fred
Released
August 28, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

Platform(s)
PlayStation Portable, PS Vita
Powered by

Dead Head Fred is still a PSP exclusive, which was released in 2007. It’s an action-adventure game set during the 1940s, and it stars a detective, Fred, who has been turned into a brain in a jar. Looking for revenge, Fred went around pummeling enemies in basic combat, but the greatest thing about the gameplay was the head system.

Players could gain heads on their journey for puzzle and combat purposes, like a bulbous one that could shoot fire. Fans of Scrubs may enjoy the game as John C. McGinley, who played Dr. Cox in the show, voiced the lead in Dead Head Fred .

Dead Nation

Top-Down Perfection

Dead Nation
Shooter
Systems
8 /10
Released
November 30, 2010
ESRB
m

Genre(s)
Shooter
Powered by

Dead Nation is one of Housemarque’s downloadable games from the PS3 generation, way before they made anything huge like Returnal . It’s a top-down shooter featuring small maps packed with endless waves of zombies. The number of zombies makes the numbers in Dead Rising games seem low, or that could be because of how dense the maps are.

Either way, players can defend themselves with plenty of weapons, explosives, and power-ups, and there is even two-player co-op. It started as a PS3 game, but it was eventually ported to the PS Vita and PS4, making it accessible today.

Stubbs The Zombie In Rebel Without A Pulse

Be The Zombie

Stubbs the Zombie in Rebel Without a Pulse
Action
Systems
Released
October 18, 2005

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Crude Humor, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Strong Language
Genre(s)
Action
Powered by

Stubbs the Zombie in Rebel Without a Pulse was originally released as an Xbox exclusive in 2005, and it remained that way until the 2021 remaster, making the game more widely available. It takes place in the 1950s, although there is some future tech.

Players assume the role of Stubbs, who is a shambling zombie with a diverse set of powers beyond chomping on enemies like they are giant ears of corn. Players can fart to freeze enemies, use their arms to control them, throw their organs as explosives, and there are even some driving segments, all of which can liven up the gameplay.

Operation Darkness

Werewolves Vs Zombies

Operation Darkness
Released
October 11, 2007

Platform(s)
Xbox 360
Powered by

Operation Darkness is an underrated tactical RPG that was exclusive to the Xbox 360, and it is set during an alternate version of World War 2. Nazis have control of a zombie army and other creatures, while players are part of a werewolf brigade.

During battle, players will move on a grid and target enemies with guns, bombs, and some powers. Operation Darkness is not the most amazing tactical RPG ever made, but the absurd premise is worth a look, and it’s a shame it is not backwards compatible on modern Xbox consoles.

Zombie Nation

Nothing But Head

Zombie Nation
Action
Arcade
Shooter
Systems
Released
December 14, 1990
Developer(s)
Live Planning, KAZe Co., Ltd.
Publisher(s)
Meldac of Japan, Meldac of America Inc.

Platform(s)
SNES
Genre(s)
Action, Arcade, Shooter
Powered by

Zombie Nation is a bit misleading for a title, because the gameplay is not about fighting an endless horde of zombies on the NES. Instead, players are a flying zombie head that can target enemy aircraft and buildings to blow up.

It’s actually a reskin of a game in Japan called Abarenbou Tengu , which has a similar premise but with a floating tengu demon head instead. To call either version weird would be an understatement, but this was the 90s, when games on the NES were anything but normal.

D2

Trapped In Snow

D2
Adventure
Survival Horror
RPG
FPS
Systems
Released
December 23, 1999

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
m
Genre(s)
Adventure, Survival Horror, RPG, FPS
Powered by

D2 is not exactly a zombie game, as it was more about aliens infesting humans to become mutants, but it still features those zombie vibes of 90s horror games, complete with poorly delivered dialogue. It was released in 1999 for the Dreamcast in Japan, while North American players had to wait a year.

The game starts with a group crashing in the snowy mountains, and then players have to escape. The shooting and movement controls were fine enough, but the coolest feature of the game was the leveling-up system, which was an early example of a horror game having one.

Deep Fear

A Silly Sega Saturn Gem

Deep Fear
Survival Horror
Systems
Released
June 30, 1998
ESRB
nr
Developer(s)
Sega

Genre(s)
Survival Horror
Powered by

Deep Fear was only released in Japan and Europe for the Sega Saturn, making it one Resident Evil clone that was a bit harder to come by in the 90s. While the acting is cheesy, it did do some interesting things for the genre at the time.

Players could move and shoot instead of standing still like most horror games at the time, and there were more guns and ammo than in typical survival horror games, and in turn, enemies did more damage. The underwater setting was utilized effectively to create atmosphere, and there were even segments where players had to use a breathing device to navigate between areas.

Night Slashers

Brawling With The Undead

Night Slashers
Beat 'Em Up
Systems
Released
1993
ESRB
e
Engine
Unity

Genre(s)
Beat 'Em Up
Powered by

Night Slashers is a rare treat for a zombie game because it’s an old-school beat ‘em up. Players can select several characters, each with different powers, and go through normal stages, fighting endless zombies along the way.

The bosses are more elaborate, like a giant Frankenstein-like monster. It’s a relatively short game, and it’s also very accessible today thanks to a recent remaster called Night Slashers: Remake . If players want a quick and cheesy co-op game to play with three others over an afternoon, this is it.

Little Red Riding Hood's Zombie BBQ

A Zombie Shoot ‘Em Up

Little Red Riding Hood's Zombie BBQ
Shooter
Systems
Released
October 31, 2008

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

Genre(s)
Shooter
Platform(s)
Nintendo DS
Powered by

Little Red Riding Hood's Zombie BBQ is one of the most obscure DS horror games to ever be released, which was a budget title at the time. It’s a vertical shooter starring Red Riding Hood, who is absolutely armed to the teeth with weaponry.

Zombies will march toward the bottom, and players will have to defend their space as the screen scrolls upward. Between her design and the zombies, the game has a very cutesy vibe to it that works among all of the blood splatter.

The Last Guy

Save The World

The Last Guy
Released
August 28, 2008

Platform(s)
PlayStation 3
Powered by

The Last Guy is a PS3-exclusive game that was made internally within Japan Studio, a Sony-based developer. Instead of focusing on fighting zombies in a top-down environment, the bigger task was to rescue as many citizens as possible in a level.

It was sort of like Pikmin, wherein players had to find citizens, gather them up, and then relocate them to save zones while avoiding zombies and other mutants. There aren’t many zombie experiences that are more like puzzle games, which made The Last Guy unique as a PS3 game, and it’s still unique now.

item.title: Say Goodbye to Diablo 4's Longest Reigning Meta Class and Welcome a New Monarch
item.description:
Diablo 4 recently released its Season of Divine Intervention, Season 11 for short. The patch that came with it made a lot of significant changes to Diablo 4 's crafting system, including how Masterworking and Tempering work, while also adding the new Sanctification step for making great items the best they can be. Yet, one could argue that the most important and least advertised parts of Season 11 were the Uber versions of the Lesser Evils and the addition of the new Paladin class, which is already a fan-favorite due to its flavor and gameplay.

New bosses, a rework of core crafting mechanics, and an entirely new class all call for a massive meta shift, and that's exactly what happened to Diablo 4 with Season 11. Season 10 had a rather clear-cut meta when it came to which classes were best to pick, and then which of their builds were the most effective at clearing endgame content. The Spiritborn was particularly good in Season 10, possibly thanks to benefiting more from Chaos Armor than other classes and builds, so it ended up dominating the charts for D4 's Pit. Now, after a long time, Season 11 is clearly no longer the Spiritborn's kingdom, but the Paladin reigns supreme.

Say Hello to the New Best Class in Diablo 4 Season 11

Diablo 4 's best Paladin builds don't boil down to just a handful of skills, as the class' kit is great overall and allows for incredible variety. Judgment builds are arguably the best right now for clearing bosses and regular enemies, but skills like Advance, Blessed Hammer, Blessed Shield, Divine Lance, Consecration, and Zenith are all fantastic options to build around for the endgame. This alone gives the Paladin more replay value compared to the Spiritborn, which has a few outstanding builds, like Evade ones and possibly Crushing Hand, but it doesn't bring much variety to the table.

Why Diablo 4's Paladin is Suddenly The Most Popular Class

Be it because it's the newest toy to play with, be it because its kit is more well-rounded, the Paladin is the clear winner of Season 11. Diablo 4 's Aura Paladin builds can even delete endgame enemies and high-tier Pit just by walking around and not using their weapons, which is a fun spin on the now classic Evade Spiritborn.

The so-called Auradin build from renowned Diablo 4 player and content creator Wudijo requires the Dawfire Unique Gloves to work.

Diablo 4 's Spiritborn builds have been dominating the game since the new class came out with Vessel of Hatred, making it all the more refreshing for a different one to take the crown in Season 11 ahead of the Lord of Hatred expansion in April 2026. Since Evade Spiritborn builds have been so good for well over one year now, having them retain their greatness while making room for all-new, fun builds for a different class is something the game needed a lot, as the recent hype around new Druid builds reveals.

Diablo 4's Paladin vs. Spiritborn: Which is Better?

Why You Should Play a Spiritborn in Diablo 4 Season 11

The main reasons why the Spiritborn is a meta class now and has been for a very long time are:

  • Diablo 4 's Evade Spiritborn is a speedy endgame clearer that's easy to use.
  • The various Quill Rain Spiritborn builds made each season are consistently strong and fast, rewarding good positioning.
  • The Spiritborn has some great guaranteed Aspects in Diablo 4 , making it very accessible and reliable.
  • The Spiritborn is a tested and true class that typically doesn't get many changes across seasons, so it's a fantastic pick for a first character in a given season, and it's easy to make the best builds in the game for it.
  • The Spiritborn has a unique power fantasy that can't be found in other classes, as it focuses on spirit animals and their guidance.

Why You Should Play a Paladin in Diablo 4 Season 11

However, the new Paladin is possibly on par with the Spiritborn, if not outright better. This is because:

  • The Paladin's Arbiter of Justice in Diablo 4 can make the otherwise more sluggish class quite speedy, even if the extra movement speed on this skill was recently nerfed in patch 2.5.1.
  • Evade Paladin builds exist and are quite powerful as an alternative to the Spiritborn.
  • The Paladin more easily enables "passive" builds like Holy Light Aura and Thorns in Diablo 4 , whereas the Spiritborn requires more buildup for equal or less effective results.
  • The Paladin is a naturally bulky class with self-healing options in multiple skills, like Consecration and Fanaticism Aura's Rite of Redemption upgrade.
  • The Aura Paladin build makes for an incredible alternative to minion builds for Necromancer and Druid with Wolf-related Aspects, powering allies up while also weakening enemies and dealing damage to them.

Ultimately, both classes have their pros and cons, but it's undeniable that the Paladin generated an incredible amount of hype for Diablo 4 's present and future, spawning not a couple, but over a dozen meta builds that mostly surpass every other option in the game. This doesn't mean that there are no outliers, as the Sorcerer's Crackling Energy build and the Rogue's Death Trap build in Diablo 4 . Yet, the Paladin is the new shiny thing, and it's understandable that it's dominating the meta while rapidly becoming a fan favorite.

9 /10

Diablo 4

Followed
Action RPG
Hack and Slash
Systems

item.title: No, I'm Not a Human: All Visitors
item.description:
There are 47 Guests that players can allow into their home in No, I'm Not a Human , and each of them has a chance of becoming a Visitor. Whether they were a Visitor when they came to your door, or they've been infected by someone inside the house, it's always a good idea to check your Guests before nightfall so that nobody has to die. Below, we've outlined the signs for all Visitors in No, I'm Not a Human , so you know what symptoms to check for without wasting Energy or making the wrong decision.

Updated on December 20, 2025, by Jake Fillery: No, I'm Not a Human receives a major content update that provides players with 12 new humans and visitors to identify. We've updated this guide with these 12 characters from the Usual Suspects Update released on December 18, 2025. If you want a comprehensive, foolproof way to identify all visitors in No, I'm Not a Human, then we've got you covered.

All Guaranteed Visitors in No, I'm Not a Human

There are 6 Guests that will always be Visitors , no matter what. This means that players should never, ever, let these people into their homes, as they will always kill. However, it's worth noting that the Cat Lady will never kill, even though she's a guaranteed Visitor. In this case, it's advised to let the Cat Lady in so that you can get the Cat and access the Basement, and then kill the Cat Lady. Here are all the Visitors you should always leave outside:

Visitor

Image

Cashier

Coat Guy

Cat Lady

Big Momma

Old Lady

Immortal Man

All Guaranteed Humans in No, I'm Not a Human

There are 9 Guests that will always be Human , meaning that you should always let them inside and never feel like you have to test them and waste energy. These characters listed below will be human every single time, so feel free to welcome them, and remember that looks can be deceiving:

Human

Image

Tall Guy

Teacher

Little Girl

Mouth-Sewn Shut Guy

FEMA Guy

The 3 Cultists

Burned Man

Widowed Woman

Blind Man

All Guests & Their Visitor Signs in No, I'm Not a Human

It's not always easy to determine whether or not someone is a Visitor in No, I'm Not a Human, as most of the characters will be a Visitor or a Human based on random chance, and not guaranteed rolls like the Guests listed above. However, there are always guaranteed tells to showcase whether someone is a Visitor, and each Guest that you let in will have a specific trait to look out for. Below, we'll showcase all Guests and what you need to look for to spot if they're a Visitor:

Guest

Visitor Signs

Little Girl

Always Human

Tall Man

Always Human

Cashier

Always Visitor

Coat Guy

Always Visitor

Widowed Woman

Always Human

Bloodshot eyes

Dark aura in photo

(Killing her sister will make her refuse tests)

Orange armpits

How to Identify Visitors in No, I'm Not a Human

As you progress through No, I'm Not a Human, you'll unlock new abilities that will allow you to check your Guests for signs to see if they are Visitors. Each night that passes, you will wake up and watch the news that informs you of how to spot Visitors. Here are all the following ways to check:

  • Teeth: Perfectly white teeth and bloodied gums are signs of a Visitor.
  • Hands: Dirty fingernails and other signs of stress on the hands are signs of a Visitor.
  • Eyes: Bloodshot eyes and fast-moving retinas are signs of a Visitor.
  • Armpits: Fungus on the armpits and hairless armpits are signs of a Visitor.
  • Photo: Dark aura in photographs and glowing red eyes are signs of a Visitor.

It's also worth noting that just because a Guest has perfectly white teeth, that doesn't mean they are a Visitor. Players should stock up on Cigarettes and Energy Drinks so that they can do multiple tests on their Guests and ensure that they have thoroughly checked everything before kicking them out or killing them. Above is a full list of all Guests and the telltale signs if they're a Visitor or not, so check carefully!

No, I'm not a Human

item.title: Best Roblox Phonk ID Codes (December 2025)
item.description:
Roblox offers thousands of different experiences, many of which feature unique gameplay and worlds. Despite this, many of them share similar features, such as the ability to play custom tracks through music items. In this guide, we'll tell you about the best Roblox phonk ID codes.

As an underground hip-hop subgenre, phonk has a unique style that can enhance your gaming experience. Fortunately, players can use specific ID codes to play these tracks, though you'll have to fulfill several requirements to unlock this feature.

Updated December 20, 2025, by Artur Novichenko: A new set of phonk sound IDs is now available on Roblox , adding more tracks to choose from. These additions include different styles of phonk that work well for intense or atmospheric moments. The available IDs give you more flexibility when customizing in-game audio. This guide is updated regularly to reflect the latest sound IDs as they appear. Checking back later ensures you don’t miss any future additions.

Best Roblox Phonk ID Codes

Phonk is great for various racing and driving simulators in Roblox . But you can also play it in other experiences, such as RPGs or battlegrounds. Players only need to know the appropriate Roblox phonk ID codes.

All music features in Roblox use ID codes. But there are so many of them that it's almost impossible to listen to them all. So, we've compiled the best Roblox phonk ID codes to save you time. Among them, you're sure to find at least a few tracks to suit your taste.

How to Use Roblox Phonk ID Codes

It's important to note that using phonk ID codes may vary in different Roblox experiences. First of all, the radio or boombox features in games are paid. In other words, before you can play the tracks you want, you'll need to pay Robux for the corresponding game pass. For example, in the Fisch experience, the Radio Gamepass costs 109 Robux.

After spending money, you'll either receive a new item or unlock a new menu option. In either case, players will be able to enter various ID codes and play their favorite tracks while playing Roblox .

item.title: Roblox: Shinobi Reborn Codes (December 2025)
item.description:
The Roblox platform has many different anime games, and Shinobi Reborn is a perfect experience for Naruto fans. There, you will be able to use various iconic techniques, some of which are only available to certain clans. The main way to get better clans and unlock more advanced abilities is Gacha, and the game features coupons that provide you with extra Spins. In this Roblox guide, we will tell you about these Shinobi Reborn codes and explain how to redeem them.

Updated December 20, 2025, by Artur Novichenko: Shinobi Reborn has received a new batch of rewards, with recent additions offering extra spins and other useful bonuses. These rewards can help you progress faster or unlock new options in the game. The latest updates focus on giving you more chances and resources to work with. This guide is updated regularly to reflect newly added rewards as they appear. Checking back later is a good way to stay informed about future updates.

All Shinobi Reborn Codes

Working Shinobi Reborn Codes

  • 8000LIKES – Gives you x50 Spins. (NEW)
  • CLANPROGRESSION – Gives you x40 Spins. (NEW)
  • WINTERUPDATE – Gives you x30 Spins. (NEW)
  • SHUTDOWNAGAIN – Gives you x20 Spins. (NEW)
  • !FREEEXP – Gives you 15,000 Exp. (Enter this code in the chat)
  • !FREETOKENS – Gives you 100 Tokens. (Enter this code in the chat)
  • 4000LIKES – Gives you x30 Spins.

Expired Shinobi Reborn Codes

  • DATAFIXING
  • SORRY4BUGS
  • 2000LIKES
  • 1400LIKES
  • 200KVISITS
  • LESSGRIND
  • WELCOME
  • 600LIKES
  • 400LIKES
  • 200LIKES
  • SHUTDOWNHEHE
  • MORECHAKRAFR
  • NOMORECODES
  • MORECODES

In Shinobi Reborn , your character can be a member of one of numerous clans, and each of them provides you with different abilities. This Roblox game allows you to change your clan by getting a new one from Gacha. This process requires you to use Spins, and luckily, there are codes that provide you with them. We highly recommend using these coupons as soon as possible before they expire.

How to Redeem Shinobi Reborn Codes

Promo codes in Shinobi Reborn are quite useful, and the rewards you can get by activating them will help you get a better clan. However, if you want to claim your freebies, you will have to learn how to redeem these coupons. Here’s a list of steps you need to follow to activate Shinobi Reborn codes:

  • Open the ChakraWorks group on Roblox and join this community.
  • Launch Shinobi Reborn and wait for the game to load.
  • Complete your character customization.
  • Once you are in the game, click on the button with the three dots icon in the upper left corner of the screen.
  • In the menu that pops up, click on the button with the open door icon.
  • After that, click on the Customization button.
  • In the Customization menu, click on the arrow on the right to open the Clan menu.
  • Enter the code you want to use in the line on the right side of the Clan menu.
  • Click on the Redeem button.
  • The reward is yours.

How to Get New Shinobi Reborn Codes

The Shinobi Reborn developers may add more promo codes in future updates, and if they do, we will list them in this guide. Feel free to bookmark our article and check it from time to time for new freebies. Also, you can follow the official Shinobi Reborn media:

  • Discord Server
